title: CA Public Transportation
text:
Public Transportation in Urbn Planning
Public Transit is a Key factor in shaping how a city/society functions 

Reduces Traffic Congestion and Pollution (sustainability)
Increases access to Jobs, Education, Healthcare, etc.
Impacts Housing affordability and community equity


Useful Analyses include:

Trends in ridership over time
Efficiency: Cost per rider or mile
Equity: Who uses transit? Where is/isn‚Äôt transit accessible?

. . .

What types of variables should we look for in a dataset/sets to conduct these useful analyses?

title: CA Public Transportation
text:
Dataset: National Transit Database (NTD)

Data is filtered from US data -> CA specific Data



# A tibble: 1 √ó 75

Discuss:

What are the variables? 
What kinds of questions can we ask?

title: CA Public Transportation
CA Public Transportation
CA Public Transportation
text:
Your Turn
Work With a partner/group to:

Filter data for specific Agency -> ‚ÄúPomona Valley Transit Authority‚Äù
Create line plot of tot_pass over time



summary |> 
  filter(Agency == "Pomona Valley Transportation Authority") |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Year, y = tot_pass)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 0.6) +
  labs(
    title = "Pomona Valley Transportation Authority Ridership Over Time",
    y = "Riders/(pop.)",
    x = "Year"
  )

title: CA Public Transportation
text:
Variables
Similar to previous dataset:

Agency


New:

stop_name/id
routetype
geomotry?



This dataset is stored as a shapefile.

title: CA Public Transportation
text:
What Is a Shapefile?
A shapefile is a special type of dataset used to:

Store geographic information
Plot points, lines, or areas on a map
Perform spatial joins and analysis

title: CA Public Transportation
section: What Can this Data Tell Us?
text:
What Can this Data Tell Us?
On its own, this data shows:

Where stops are located
How many stops an agency operates
How often stop is used/How many routes serve a stop


What the data doesn‚Äôt show is:

Who lives near a certain stop
What the area is like demographically
Whether transit access is equitable

title: CA Public Transportation
text:
Adding Context


A common data wrangling practice used to connect variable that share a common identifier is called joining


We can use functions like right_join() or left_join() to connect our stop_data to a data set with socioeconomic identifiers.

title: CA Public Transportation
text: Mathlinks Lesson on Joining

title: CA Public Transportation
text:
Adding Context

Each stop in our stop_data is connected to a GEOID
In our census data, each GEOID has information on the areas demographics and socioeconomic indicators



This means we can joing these 2 datasets on the variable GEOID !




library(tidyverse)
library(sf)


joined_data <- stop_data |> 
  left_join(st_drop_geometry(census_data), by = "GEOID")

title: DS4HS
text:
Initial Dataset from US Department of Transportation titled ‚ÄúMonthly Modal Time Series‚Äù
Filtered to California Specific Data for higher relevance. Filter Specifically to your state or area fr a dataset that‚Äôs easier for students to explore and model.


library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(stringr)
pt_data <- read.csv("NTD_TimeSeries.csv")

pt_data1 <- pt_data|>
  filter(str_detect(Primary.UZA.Name, "CA$"))

write_csv(pt_data1, "ca_transit.csv")

title: DS4HS
text:
Initial Dataset from US Department of Transportation titled ‚ÄúMonthly Modal Time Series‚Äù
Filtered to California Specific Data for higher relevance. Filter Specifically to your state or area fr a dataset that‚Äôs easier for students to explore and model.


library(readr)
library(tidyverse)
library(stringr)
pt_data <- read.csv("NTD_TimeSeries.csv")

pt_data1 <- pt_data|>
  filter(str_detect(Primary.UZA.Name, "CA$"))

write_csv(pt_data1, "ca_transit.csv")

title: DS4HS
text:
2 Dataset: National Transit Database (NTD)
Discuss: The goal here is to get students to understand that the NTD dataset itself desnot caontain enough information for the insighful analysis we are looking for.

title: DS4HS
text:
3 Cleaning Distribution Materials
creating shapefile folder that joins public transit data with CA census tracts.

library(sf)
library(tigris)
library(tidyverse)

# Original sf at California Open Data Portal titled "California Transit Stops"
cts_sf <- st_read("cts_sf")

# pulling geography from Tigris and transforming to uniform CRS (NAD83)
ca_tracts <- tracts(state = "CA", year = 2024, class = "sf")
stops_sf <- st_transform(cts_sf, crs = st_crs(ca_tracts))

# Joining where stop is within tract
stops_with_tract <- st_join(stops_sf, ca_tracts, join = st_within)

clean_sf <- stops_with_tract|>
  select(agency, stop_id, stop_name, routetypes, n_arrivals, n_hours_in, district_n, COUNTYFP, TRACTCE, GEOID, geometry)

# Creates sf folder in working directory
dir.create("output_shapefile")
st_write(clean_sf, "output_shapefile/CA_Transit_Stops.shp", delete_layer = TRUE)

Retrieving census data from tidycensus package

# Pulling relevant variables
vars <- c(median_income = "B19013_001",
          num_pov = "B17001_002",
          avg_commute = "DP03_0025",
          no_vehicle = "B08201_002",
          white = "B02001_002",
          black = "B02001_003",
          asian = "B02001_005",
          hispanic_latino = "B03003_003",
          transit_users = "B08301_010",
          tot_workers = "B08301_001",
          total_pop = "B02001_001"
          )

# Retrieve unique API here "https://api.census.gov/data/key_signup.html"
library(tidycensus)

census_data <- get_acs(
  geography = "tract",
  variables = vars,
  state = "CA",
  year = 2023, # Most recent acs5 survey
  survey = "acs5",
  geometry = FALSE)

# Cleaning and Transforming Data
census_data1 <- census_data |>
  select(GEOID, variable, estimate)|>
  pivot_wider(names_from = variable, values_from = estimate) |>
  mutate(pctpoc = ((black + hispanic_latino + asian ) / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pctpov = (num_pov / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pct_wo_car = (no_vehicle / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pct_transit_users = 100 * (transit_users / total_pop))|>
  mutate(GEOID = as.character(GEOID))|>
  select(-black, -asian, -white, -hispanic_latino, -no_vehicle, -num_pov, -transit_users)

write_csv(census_data1, "acs_clean_data.csv")

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
Key Idea: Data science is about extracting insight from data to inform action.
Focus on applications of data science that connect to students interests
Ask students to add their own example of data science they‚Äôve seen and why they suspect it to be data science.

Emphasis on Data science and Urban Planning as a cycle that is repetitive. There is always new data being collected and new solutions to be found. This opens up possibilities for limitless data exploration within the field which makes it an amazing introductory example of data science for beginner students.

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
Key Idea: Data science is about extracting insight from data to inform action.
Focus on applications of data science that connect to students interests
Ask students to add their own example of data science they‚Äôve seen and why they suspect it to be data science.

Emphasis on Data science and Urban Planning as a cycle that is repetitive. There is always new data being collected and new solutions to be found. This opens up possibilities for limitless data exploration within the field which makes it an amazing introductory example of data science for beginner students.

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
section: 2 Tree Coverage as a Social Issue
text:
2 Tree Coverage as a Social Issue

Remember This concept might be difficult for students to grasp. ‚ÄúHow does the amount of trees in my neighborhood affect me?‚Äù
Ask Students, ‚ÄúWhat does a tree do? What is its purpose‚Äù Answers might be ‚ÄúProvides Shade‚Äù or ‚ÄúCreates Oxygen‚Äù These are already good markers to highlight disparity but informing students of trees other functions and how their presence in a community or the lack thereof can make a large difference in the well-being of its members will help make their studies feel relevant and impactful.

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
3 Understanding the Tree Equity Score
Here you can find the methodology behind American Forests Tree Equity Research.

The Tree Equity Score represents the Need for tree planting in an area. Need or Priority in a neighborhood is calculated by a number of factors that may highlight the potential for the area to be disproportionately affected by extreme heat, pollution and other environmental hazards which could be reduced with the benefits of trees.

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
4 Foundational Learning
DS4HS places a priority on shifting the narrative on data scienc and its accessibility. One of the main goals of this curriculum is to make content as tangible as possible for those with little to no experience in data or statistical analysis. This section introduces key concepts in data science and we want to make sure these concepts are grasped as thoroughly as possible.

Observation vs.¬†Observational Unit: Be explicit‚Äîeach row is one observation, and the observational unit is the ‚Äúthing‚Äù each row represents (e.g., a tree, a bus stop, a city block). In this example the ‚ÄúGEOID‚Äù represents one city block group.
Ask: ‚ÄúWhat is one row describing?‚Äù Have students answer in plain language.
Variable Types: Clarify the difference between categorical and numerical variables. Use color/highlight in your slides or board to mark a few examples from the dataset. Students often confuse column headers for variable values. Reinforce that variables are columns, values are entries in rows.
If possible, have students follow along in R to observe the data set. This can help them get used to the variable names and what a typical value looks like for a given variable.

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
5 Mathlink Cubes
In every lesson, there is some sort of interactive portion to help students grasp the task of data wrangling through a physical simulation of the practice.
This example comes from an article in the Journal of Statistics and Data Science Learning (McGowan 2025). Using Mathlink Cubes to Introduce Data Wrangling[^1] helps to facilitate a tangible understanding of datasets and data manipulation.
This example can also be replicated with paper strips and squares (though the creation of these materials may be tedious.)

Hand out Mathlink Cubes to students in the form of ‚Äúa dataset‚Äù meaning cubes are arranged in columns by color. Dependending on the size of your data set(amount of rows), students will need that many blocks of a unique colored block for the mutate example.

The images below show the process of connecting the Mathlink cubes inta a data-like structure that can be purposfulley taken apart and reconstructed by students.
First, connect one column vertically.

Next, connect one row horizontally, anchored to the first cube in your columnn.

Each subsequent row should then be connected horizontally and connected to a cube in the first column:

Finally, reconstruct your first column vertically and you should be left with something like this:

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
6 Teaching tidyverse and ggplot
The worksheet below is intended to follow along with the ‚ÄúTree Equity Lesson‚Äù lecture slides. The goal of an activity like this is to help students commit data wrangling and visualization strategies to memory and think bout the processes critically.
In-Class Data Wrangling Practice

6.1 Core Goals

Students experience transforming a dataset using tidyverse data verbs
They start asking questions of the data: Who‚Äôs impacted? Where? What relationships exist?
Students see visualization as a tool for insight, not just graphics.



6.2 Pedagogical Tips and Emphases
1. Emphasize the ‚Äúverbs‚Äù as actions

Anchor each function to a mental model:

filter() = ‚Äúcut out rows you don‚Äôt need‚Äù
select() = ‚Äúkeep only the columns you care about‚Äù
mutate() = ‚Äúmake new columns using calucaltions with exsisting ones‚Äù
groupby() = ‚ÄúSort data into baskets by value‚Äù
summarize() = ‚ÄúPull out the big-picture‚Äù


2. Highlight data types when visualizing

Categorical ‚Üí bar/column
Continuous ‚Üí histogram, scatter
Time-based ‚Üí line plot
Encourage asking: ‚ÄúWhat kind of variable is this? What would help me see patterns?‚Äù

3. Don‚Äôt skip reading outputs

Stop after each code chunk and ask: ‚ÄúWhat changed? What does this output tell us?‚Äù
It‚Äôs easy for students to focus on syntax and miss what the data is really saying.

4. Ask real-world connection questions

‚ÄúWhat trend do you notice?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhat might explain that relationship?‚Äù, ‚ÄúWhat other variable might influence both?‚Äù
Encourage students to answer these questions in normal and confortable language rather than expecting a more refined ‚Äúdata-sciency‚Äù answer. This will help bridge the gap between their common sense and trained data analysis

title: Tree Equity Instructor Guide
text:
7 Student Exploration + Final Project
This capstone activity gives students the chance to apply everything they‚Äôve learned from the lesson. It should feel open-ended and empowering, encouraging curiosity and creative problem-solving.
This is also the moment where data becomes personal and meaningful: students choose their question, their variables, and their visualization. The instructor‚Äôs role shifts from direct teaching to coaching, guiding students to sharpen questions, troubleshoot code, and draw clear, grounded conclusions. A presenation template for this project is provided below as a .qmd file.
Download Student Quarto Guide 

7.1 Group Work Guidance
Students should work in groups of 2‚Äì4, ideally with access to a shared device
Encourage them to:

Settle on a single state or comparison they find interesting.
Write out a clear, answerable question (this may take several revisions).

Students will use R studio to generate at least one graph and one statistical summary.
Instructors or mentors should:

Circulate and offer help with debugging.
Ask clarifying questions to refine vague research questions.
‚ÄúWhat are you trying to compare? What variable would show that?‚Äù



7.2 Managing Student Presentations
Each group should give a short (~3‚Äì4 min) presentation of:

Their question/data use
Their data wrangling process
Their plot(s) and the trends they suggest
A brief interpretation: ‚ÄúWhat does this mean?‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhy does it matter?‚Äù

While students present:

Highlight clarity of visualizations, originality of questions, or insightful interpretations.
Celebrate one strong point from each group to model good data science communication. For Example,

‚ÄúWhat I loved about this presentation was how clear the graph labels were ‚Äî it helped us understand the pattern immediately.‚Äù

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: üåê The Big Idea: Why Urban Planning
text:
üåê The Big Idea: Why Urban Planning

Urban planning IS data science in action.

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: HOW??

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
What is Data Science??

From IBM US: Data science is the practice of ‚Äúuncovering actionable insights hidden in data. These insights can be used to guide decision making and strategic planning.‚Äù
üéì Schools study attendance and grade trends to identify students who may need extra support before they fall behind.
üè• Hospitals use patient records and trends to predict who‚Äôs at risk for certain illnesses ‚Äî helping doctors intervene earlier.

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: Data Science Cycle -> Urban Planning Cycle
text: Data Science Cycle -> Urban Planning Cycle

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: üå≥ Introduction: Tree Equity and City Planning
text:
üå≥ Introduction: Tree Equity and City Planning

Tree Planting is a direct action of City Planning Initiatives
Why do some neighborhoods have less trees than others? How are these Neighborhoods affected? What can we do?

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
American Forests: Tree Equity Score


Tree Canopy Coverage‚Ä¶

Improves Air Quality and Stabalizes Enviromental Hazzards
Intercepts Rainfall and prevents Stormwater Runnoff
Reduces Heat extremity improving peoples physical and mental health

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Todays Goals

Learn to use R for data analysis and communication
Understand what makes a dataset meaningful
Ask important questions about data and the observed world
Explore how data can inform just and sustainable practices

text:
An Observation

Person
County
State
Country

The GEOID or Census block Group describes a particular community or neighborhood in a given area contains between 600 - 3,000 people 1

American Forests Methods and Data Glossary

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
What are the Variables?

treecanopy: Actual tree coverage in an area
tc_goal: Ideal tree coverage based on needs
tc_gap: How far behind the area is (tc_goal - treecanopy)
pctpocnorm: % residents who are people of color
pctpovnorm, unemplnorm: Indicators of equity
lingnorm: % of non-english households (linguistic isolation)
tes: Tree Equity Score (gap √ó need)

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: What do we want to know
text:
What do we want to know

Its not always easy to start analyzing such a large data set. Thats why it is important to ask SMART questions
Specific: Clear, detailed, and not too broad
Measureable: Can be answered using the available data
Applicable: Tied to real-world meaningful contexts
Reasoned: Based on logic or a thoughtful assumption
Testable: Can be analyzed to reveal patterns or relationships

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
SMART vs.¬†Not-so-SMART Questions
Don‚Äôt ask:

Is ‚Äúgiven neighborhood‚Äù affected?
Does tree coverage matter?


Instead ask:

How does tree coverage relate to income in LA neighborhoods?
Is the tree coverage gap higher in areas with high unemployment?

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: Going From Question to Answer

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Data Wrangling
Before we can answer our questions, we need to prepare the data.

Data wrangling includes:

Cleaning messy or incomplete data
Selecting the most relevant information
Reshaping data into a usable form
Creating new variables that help us analyze



Think of it like organizing your workspace before starting a project.

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: Mathlink Cubes

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
filter(): Keep Certain Rows
filter() lets us select only the rows that meet specific conditions.

filter(red == "triangle")

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
select(): Keep Certain Columns
select() lets us keep only the variables (columns) we care about.

select(red, green)

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: mutate(): Add a New Insightful Column
text:
mutate(): Add a New Insightful Column
mutate() lets us create a new column (variable) by transforming existing ones.

# Triangle = yes, Square = no
mutate(is_hexagon = (blue == "hexagon"))

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
arrange(): Ordering our data
arrange() Sort rows by the values of a variable (ascending or descending).

# Hexagon ‚Üí Square ‚Üí Triangle ‚Üí Pentagon.
arrange(purple)

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: group_by() and summarise(): Summariing by Category
text:
group_by() and summarise(): Summariing by Category
group_by() lets us group the data by a specific variable.

group_by(yellow)|> 
summarize(count = n())

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: Now you Try

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Compute the average tes score by place


Hint: group_by() and summarise()



ca_tes |>
  group_by(place) |>
  summarize(avg_tes = mean(tes, na.rm = TRUE))

   place        avg_tes
   <chr>          <dbl>

 5 Alamo           99.2
 6 Albany          90.2
 7 Alhambra        73.0
 8 Aliso Viejo     85.7
 9 Alondra Park    65.7
10 Alpine          74.1

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: Which neighborhoods have the greatest tree equity need?

title: Tree Equity Lesson
section: How does tree equity relate to both poverty and health disparity?
text:
How does tree equity relate to both poverty and health disparity?

create variable combined_index that connects pctpovnorm and health_nor
cut data set down to desired variables (place, combined_index, and tes)
organize data to see which places have highest combined index



ca_tes|>
  filter(!is.na(pctpovnorm), !is.na(health_nor))|>
  mutate(combined_index = pctpov * health_nor)|>
  select(place, combined_index, tes)|>
  arrange(desc(combined_index))

# A tibble: 24,253 √ó 3
   place      combined_index   tes
   <chr>               <dbl> <dbl>
 1 Napa                1        69
 2 Chowchilla          0.997    61
 3 Hanford             0.920    26
 4 Wasco               0.908    37
 5 Shafter             0.903    58
 6 Arvin               0.899    24
 7 Delano              0.899    30
 8 Shafter             0.876    44
 9 Brawley             0.875    50
10 Rosamond            0.875    18
# ‚Ñπ 24,243 more rows

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: Visualizing the Data

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
What and Why

Data visualization is the process of transforming raw data into visual formats, like charts, graphs, or maps, to make it easier to understand and interpret
Communicate Results Clearly and Effectively
Supports evidence-based decisions in fields like:

Public health
Climate research
Urban planning
Business & marketing

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
What is ggplot2?

ggplot2 is an R package for data visualization.
Encoded functions for numerous different plot types
Builds plots in layers using +

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Basic Structure of a ggplot

# General structure
data|>
  ggplot(aes(x = ..., y = ...)) +
  geom_function() +
  labs("label for you plot and axes")

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Common geom() functions

geom_point(): scatterplots (x vs y)
geom_bar(): bar charts (categorical data)
geom_col(): bar chart with height from y var
geom_histogram(): distribution of numeric variable
geom_line(): trends over continuous x-axis

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Which plot should I use?










Variable Type
Plot Type
geom()?
When to Use




Categorical
Bar Chart
geom_bar()
Count frequency of categories


Continuous
Histogram
geom_histogram()
Show distribution of one variables


Continuous + Continuous
Scatter Plot
geom_point()
Explore relationships between vars


Continuous + Time
Line Chart
geom_line()
Show change over time


Category + Value
Column Chart
geom_col()
Compare totals across categories

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Types of Variables

insert graphic on variable types

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Tree Equity vs.¬†Poverty

Is there a relationship between poverty and tree equity?



ca_tes|>
  ggplot(aes(x = pctpov, y = tes)) +
  geom_point(color = "green") + 
  labs(title = "Tree Equity vs. Poverty",
       x = "Percent in Poverty",
       y = "Tree Equity Score")

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Distribution of Tree Equity Scores

How many places have each Tree equity score?



ca_tes|>
  ggplot(aes(x = tes)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15, fill = "red") +
  labs(title = "Distribution of Tree Equity Scores",
       x = "Tree Equity Score",
       y = "Number of Places")

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Tree Equity vs.¬†Linguistic Isolation

Is there a relationship between linnguistic isolation(lingnorm) and tes in an area.


Use ggplot to plot the relationship between tes and lingnorm
Choose the best plot for the variable types
Create fitting labels for your axes and plot title

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
ca_tes|>
  ggplot(aes(x = lingnorm, y = tes)) +
  geom_point(color = "turquoise") + 
  labs(title = "Tree Equity vs. Linguistiv Isolation",
       x = "Percent in Linguistic Isolation",
       y = "Tree Equity Score")

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text: ‚ÄúExplore, Analyze, Present!‚Äù

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Its Your Turn

You will work in small groups to investigate tree equity in a new state(s)


Each Group Will: 

Choose a research question(s)

Use tidyverse tools to explore the data

Create plot(s) with ggplot2

Present findings to the class

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Your Goals

Clearly state your research question

Support it with r code and graphs

Use the data to identify a trend, pattern, or disparity

Communicate WHY it matters

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Examples Questions

How does tree canopy vary across different neighborhoods in chosen state?

Is there a relationship between percent in poverty and tree equity score in chosen state?
How do tree equity trends compare between two or more chosen states?

Are places with lower tree equity also more likely to have higher health disparities in chosen state?

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
Getting the Data
Navigate to treeequityscore.org:

in drop down menu on top left, click ‚Äúmethods and data‚Äù tab
choose the ‚Äúdata download‚Äù page and you should see something like this:

title: Tree Equity Lesson
text:
# Example code to load your state data

library(readr)
you_data_name <- read_csv("path_to_your_data.csv")

title: DS4HS
text: Welcome to DS4HS: Data Science for High School, a community-centered, educational initiative hosted at Pomona College. Our Saturday workshops are designed to introduce high school students to the powerful world of data science. Through hands on activities and interactive coding practice, our aim is to make the field of data science accessible to those of any educational background. Whether you‚Äôre exploring data for the first time or deepening existing skills, DS4HS aims to create a collaborative and engaging space for all learners. Our curriculum is open-source and accessible, supporting both student exploration and teacher development.

title: DS4HS and PAYS
text: Website Work

title: DS4HS and PAYS
text: Website Work

title: DS4HS and PAYS
section: Data Wrangling for Public Transit Problem
text:
Data Wrangling for Public Transit Problem

# Original sf at California Open Data Portal titled "California Transit Stops"
cts_sf <- st_read("cts_sf")

# pulling geography from Tigris and transforming to uniform CRS (NAD83)
ca_tracts <- tracts(state = "CA", year = 2024, class = "sf")
stops_sf <- st_transform(cts_sf, crs = st_crs(ca_tracts))

# Joining where stop is within tract
stops_with_tract <- st_join(stops_sf, ca_tracts, join = st_within)

clean_sf <- stops_with_tract|>
  select(agency, stop_id, stop_name, routetypes, n_arrivals, n_hours_in, district_n, COUNTYFP, TRACTCE, GEOID, geometry)

# Creates sf folder in working directory
dir.create("output_shapefile")
st_write(clean_sf, "output_shapefile/CA_Transit_Stops.shp", delete_layer = TRUE)

title: DS4HS and PAYS
text: PAYS

title: DS4HS and PAYS
text: Website Work

title: DS4HS and PAYS
section: Data Wrangling for Public Transit Problem
text:
Data Wrangling for Public Transit Problem

# Pulling relevant variables
vars <- c(median_income = "B19013_001",
          num_pov = "B17001_002",
          avg_commute = "DP03_0025",
          no_vehicle = "B08201_002",
          white = "B02001_002",
          black = "B02001_003",
          asian = "B02001_005",
          hispanic_latino = "B03003_003",
          transit_users = "B08301_010",
          tot_workers = "B08301_001",
          total_pop = "B02001_001"
          )

# Retrieve unique API here "https://api.census.gov/data/key_signup.html"
library(tidycensus)

census_data <- get_acs(
  geography = "tract",
  variables = vars,
  state = "CA",
  year = 2023, # Most recent acs5 survey
  survey = "acs5",
  geometry = FALSE)

# Cleaning and Transforming Data
census_data1 <- census_data |>
  select(GEOID, variable, estimate)|>
  pivot_wider(names_from = variable, values_from = estimate) |>
  mutate(pctpoc = ((black + hispanic_latino + asian ) / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pctpov = (num_pov / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pct_wo_car = (no_vehicle / total_pop) * 100)|>
  mutate(pct_transit_users = 100 * (transit_users / total_pop))|>
  mutate(GEOID = as.character(GEOID))|>
  select(-black, -asian, -white, -hispanic_latino, -no_vehicle, -num_pov, -transit_users)

write_csv(census_data1, "acs_clean_data.csv")
